abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Emergency Drought Recovery and
            Mitigation Project in Zambia. The two principal objectives
            of the program were: (a) to address the risk of widespread
            famine in Zimbabwe; and (b) to provide the conditions under
            which the productive sectors could rebound quickly from the
            drought.  Bank's performance was satisfactory.
            Borrower's performance was satisfactory. The key
            lessons learned were as follows: (i) approval to procure
            inputs must be given in time whilst sourcing for funds is
            still in progress; (ii) there is need for government to
            provide enough funds for the whole project especially if the
            component involves different ministries; (iii) the project
            revealed the capacity constraint of government agencies in
            implementing emergency drought relief operations
            effectively; (iv) government should encourage and provide
            incentives for input suppliers to invest in input
            distribution warehouses in small holder farm areas; (v)
            planning should not be centralised and whenever possible
            involve all levels and layers of beneficiaries to enable
            transparency and acceptability; (vi) emergency procurement
            procedures need to be more carefully designed and fully
            articulated at appraisal stage; (vii) the government Tender
            Board should be requested to process emergency tenders on
            their own instead of mixing them with other tenders; and
            (viii) during the identification and appraisal stage,
            Government should play a more significant role inorder to
            influence project design.
